newsitem.title: BOSNIA: German defence minister visits NATO troops.
newsitem.headline: German defence minister visits NATO troops.

text.p: German Defence Minister Volker Ruehe on Wednesday visited his country's combat troops serving in the NATO-led peace force in Bosnia as they prepared formally to assume their duties.

Ruehe flew into the Bosnian capital Sarajevo to attend a ceremony in which Major-General Klaus Fruhhaber will declare his 2,000-strong contingent ready to assume its peacekeeping mission in the Stabilisation Force (SFOR).

Equipped with armoured personnel carriers and reconnaissance vehicles, the German soldiers will be under French command in the southwest near the town of Mostar inside Bosnia's Moslem-Croat federation

The first deployment of German combat troops since World War Two has so far sparked no angry reaction among the former warring factions despite memories of atrocities committed during the Nazi occupation of old Yugoslavia.
Apart from the 2,000 soldiers serving in Bosnia itself, Germany has contributed another 1,000 airmen, sailors and other combat troops to the NATO-led force in former Yugoslavia.
Some 31,000 troops from the NATO alliance and other countries are policing the Dayton peace agreement in Bosnia in an 18-month mission due to expire in mid-1998.
